docs.lead_paragraph: At 7 o'clock on Monday evenings, a tutor comes to Serita Armstrong's Brooklyn apartment, and Ms. Armstrong's 8-year-old identical twins, Nailah and Nabilah, head to the kitchen table and start their lessons. The third graders see their tutor four times a week. Ms. Armstrong, 37, wants a better and bigger life for her twins and their 12-year-old sister, Medina Singletary. She wants them to excel.

headline.main: The Neediest Cases; Despite Struggles, the Goal Is Always to Be Productive

docs.abstract: Serita Armstrong, disabled after fall on job, received assistance from Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, supported by New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, that allows her to keep home and family intact while she pursues new career; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Togo has become one of few African countries to legalize abortion if the pregnancy is a result of rape or an incestuous relationship, according to a copy of a new law. Abortion is illegal in most African countries unless medics deem the procedure necessary to protect the woman’s life or physical health. Togo’s new law will also allow abortion “if there is a strong risk that the unborn child will by affected by a particularly serious medical condition.” Birthrates in West Africa are among the highest in the world, and modern contraceptives are not universally available.
